_**The Mask**_ is a 1994 American [superhero](/wiki/Superhero_film "Superhero
film") [fantasy](/wiki/Fantasy_film "Fantasy film") [comedy
film](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film") directed by [Charles
Russell](/wiki/Chuck_Russell "Chuck Russell"), produced by Bob Engelman, and
written by [Mike Werb](/wiki/Mike_Werb "Mike Werb"), based on the [comic
series of the same name](/wiki/The_Mask "The Mask") distributed by [Dark Horse
Comics](/wiki/Dark_Horse_Comics "Dark Horse Comics"). The film stars [Jim
Carrey](/wiki/Jim_Carrey "Jim Carrey"), [Peter Greene](/wiki/Peter_Greene
"Peter Greene"), [Amy Yasbeck](/wiki/Amy_Yasbeck "Amy Yasbeck"), [Peter
Riegert](/wiki/Peter_Riegert "Peter Riegert"), [Richard
Jeni](/wiki/Richard_Jeni "Richard Jeni"), [Ben Stein](/wiki/Ben_Stein "Ben
Stein"), [Joely Fisher](/wiki/Joely_Fisher "Joely Fisher"), and [Cameron
Diaz](/wiki/Cameron_Diaz "Cameron Diaz") in her film debut. It revolves around
an unlucky bank clerk finding a mask that grants the wearer cartoon-like
superpowers.

The film was released on July 29, 1994 by [New Line
Cinema](/wiki/New_Line_Cinema "New Line Cinema"), becoming a critical and
commercial [blockbuster](/wiki/Blockbuster_\(entertainment\) "Blockbuster
\(entertainment\)"), grossing over $351.6 million over a $23 million budget
and receiving positive reviews. It cemented Carrey's reputation as a dominant
actor of the 1990s, and established Diaz long-term as a [leading
lady](/wiki/Leading_lady "Leading lady"). Carrey was nominated for a [Golden
Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe "Golden Globe") for his role, and the film was
nominated for the [Academy Award for Best Visual
Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects "Academy Award for Best
Visual Effects") but lost to _[Forrest Gump](/wiki/Forrest_Gump "Forrest
Gump")_.

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Stanley Ipkiss is a shy and unlucky [bank clerk](/wiki/Bank_clerk "Bank
clerk") working at the local Edge City bank. He is frequently ridiculed by
everyone around him, except for his [Jack Russell
Terrier](/wiki/Jack_Russell_Terrier "Jack Russell Terrier") Milo, and his co-
worker and best friend Charlie Schumaker. Meanwhile, gangster Dorian Tyrell,
owner of the Coco Bongo nightclub, plots to overthrow his boss Niko. One day,
Tyrell sends his singer girlfriend Tina Carlyle into Stanley's bank to record
its layout, in preparation to rob the bank.

Stanley is attracted to Tina, and she seems to reciprocate. Unable to enter
the Coco Bongo to watch Tina perform, Stanley finds a wooden mask near the
city's harbor. Placing it on his face transforms him into a green-faced,
[zoot-suited](/wiki/Zoot_suit "Zoot suit"), bizarre, wisecracking trickster
known as the Mask, who is able to cartoonishly alter himself and his
surroundings at will. Stanley exacts revenge on his tormentors and scares off
a street gang that attempts to rob him by [turning a
balloon](/wiki/Balloon_modelling "Balloon modelling") into a [Tommy
gun](/wiki/Tommy_gun "Tommy gun").

The next morning, Stanley encounters detective Lieutenant Kellaway and
newspaper reporter Peggy Brandt investigating the Mask's activity of the
previous night. To attend Tina's performance, he again becomes the Mask to
raid the bank, inadvertently foiling Tyrell's plan in the process. At the Coco
Bongo, Stanley dances exuberantly with Tina, whom he ends up kissing.
Following a confrontation with Tyrell for disrupting the bank robbery, Stanley
flees leaving behind a scrap of cloth from his suit that transforms back into
his pajamas, while Tyrell and his men are arrested by Kellaway and his partner
Doyle.

Based on the piece of cloth, Kellaway suspects Stanley to be the bank robber.
Stanley later consults a psychiatrist who has recently published a book on
masks and is discovered that the object may be a depiction of
[Loki](/wiki/Loki "Loki"), the [Norse](/wiki/Norse_mythology "Norse
mythology") god of darkness and mischief. The same night, Stanley meets Tina
at a local park as the Mask, but the meeting is interrupted by Kellaway, who
attempts to capture him. Stanley tricks a large group of police officers into
joining him in a mass-performance of the [Desi Arnaz](/wiki/Desi_Arnaz "Desi
Arnaz") song "Cuban Pete" and flees with Peggy, but she betrays him to Tyrell
for a $50,000 bounty. Using the mask, Tyrell becomes a malevolent green-faced
monster. Tyrell's henchmen ends up in the possession of the stolen money after
Stanley is forced to reveal its location; and they turn Stanley in to the
police.

When Tina visits Stanley in the station, he urges her to flee the city. Tina
thanks Stanley for his generosity and tells him that she knew he was the Mask
all along. She attempts to leave the city, but is captured by Tyrell's men and
forcibly taken to a charity ball at the Coco Bongo hosted by Niko and attended
by the city's elite, including Mayor Tilton. Upon arrival, the masked Tyrell
kills Niko and prepares to destroy both the club and Tina with dynamite. Milo
helps Stanley escape from the station, and Stanley brings Kellaway as a cover
and hostage in a desperate attempt to stop Tyrell.

After locking Kellaway in his car, Stanley enters the club and manages to
enlist the help of Charlie, but is soon after discovered and captured. Tina
tricks Tyrell into taking off the mask, which is recovered and donned by Milo,
who fights Tyrell's men, while Stanley fights Tyrell, himself. After
recovering the mask, Stanley uses its special powers to rescue Tina by
swallowing Tyrell's bomb and flushing Tyrell down the drain of the club's
ornamental fountain. The police arrive and arrest Tyrell's remaining henchmen
and attempt to capture Stanley once again. However, Tilton tells Kellaway to
release Stanley because Tyrell was the Mask the whole time and Tilton calls
Stanley a hero for his actions.

As the sun rises the following day, all charges against Stanley are dropped.
To avoid getting involved with the police again, Stanley decides to return the
mask back to the harbor. Tina throws the mask into the water, and she and
Stanley kiss. Charlie then jumps in the water to retrieve the mask for
himself, only to find Milo swimming away with it.

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Jim Carrey](/wiki/Jim_Carrey "Jim Carrey") as [Stanley Ipkiss / The Mask](/wiki/The_Mask "The Mask"). Carrey commented that he characterized Stanley after his own father: "a nice guy, just trying to get by".[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Carrey was paid $450,000 for starring in the film, which was a huge bargain for New Line Cinema at the time.
  * [Cameron Diaz](/wiki/Cameron_Diaz "Cameron Diaz") as Tina Carlyle, Dorian Tyrell's girlfriend and lounge singer at the Coco Bongo who later becomes Stanley's love interest. This role marked the feature film debut for Cameron Diaz. Before Diaz was cast, the studio considered casting [Anna Nicole Smith](/wiki/Anna_Nicole_Smith "Anna Nicole Smith"), [Vanessa Williams](/wiki/Vanessa_Williams "Vanessa Williams") and [Kristy Swanson](/wiki/Kristy_Swanson "Kristy Swanson"). After Diaz auditioned twelve times for the role, she was finally cast only a week before filming began.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * [Peter Greene](/wiki/Peter_Greene "Peter Greene") as Dorian Tyrell, a mobster who wants to take over the city's underworld. Greene was cast after the studio's top choice, [Gary Kemp](/wiki/Gary_Kemp "Gary Kemp"), turned it down.
  * [Richard Jeni](/wiki/Richard_Jeni "Richard Jeni") as Charlie Schumaker, Stanley's best friend and colleague.
  * [Peter Riegert](/wiki/Peter_Riegert "Peter Riegert") as Lt. Mitch Kellaway, a cynical police detective who hunts the Mask, as well as Tyrell and Niko. Before Riegert was cast, the studio considered [Richard Gere](/wiki/Richard_Gere "Richard Gere") for the role.
  * [Jim Doughan](/wiki/Jim_Doughan "Jim Doughan") as Det. Doyle, Lt. Kellaway's dim-witted partner.
  * [Amy Yasbeck](/wiki/Amy_Yasbeck "Amy Yasbeck") as Peggy Brandt, a reporter with a crush on Stanley. In a deleted scene, Peggy is killed by Tyrell shortly after he first puts the mask on.
  * [Orestes Matacena](/wiki/Orestes_Matacena "Orestes Matacena") as Niko, a Greek mafia boss and Tyrell's nemesis.
  * [Eamonn Roche](/wiki/Eamonn_Roche "Eamonn Roche") as Mr. Dickey, the son of the Bank President who is Stanley and Charlie's superior.
  * [Nancy Fish](/w/index.php?title=Nancy_Fish&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nancy Fish \(page does not exist\)") as Mrs. Peenman, Stanley's grumpy land-lady.
  * [Tim Bagley](/wiki/Tim_Bagley "Tim Bagley") as Irv Ripley, a mechanic who rips off Stanley.
  * Johnny Williams as Burt Ripley, a mechanic and Irv's brother.
  * [Reginald E. Cathey](/wiki/Reg_E._Cathey "Reg E. Cathey") as Freeze (called The Doctor in the film), Dorian Tyrell's trusted lieutenant and friend whose death, inadvertently caused by The Mask, drives Tyrell into a personal vendetta against Ipkiss.
  * [Denis Forest](/wiki/Denis_Forest "Denis Forest") as Sweet Eddy, one of Tyrell's henchmen. Before Forest was cast, the studio considered [Chris Elliott](/wiki/Chris_Elliott "Chris Elliott") for the role.
  * [Nils Allen Stewart](/w/index.php?title=Nils_Allen_Stewart&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nils Allen Stewart \(page does not exist\)") as Orlando, another of Tyrell's henchmen.
  * [Ivory Ocean](/w/index.php?title=Ivory_Ocean&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ivory Ocean \(page does not exist\)") as Mayor Mitchell Tilton, the mayor of Edge City.
  * [Joely Fisher](/wiki/Joely_Fisher "Joely Fisher") as Maggie, another one of Stanley's colleagues.
  * [Ben Stein](/wiki/Ben_Stein "Ben Stein") as Dr. Arthur Neuman, Stanley's psychologist. He is the only character to appear in both _The Mask_ and its sequel _[Son of the Mask](/wiki/Son_of_the_Mask "Son of the Mask")_.
  * [Royal Crown Revue](/wiki/Royal_Crown_Revue "Royal Crown Revue") as themselves / The Coco Bongo Band

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

In 1989, Mike Richardson and Todd Moyer (who was Executive Vice President of
Dark Horse Comics) first approached New Line Cinema about adapting the comic
_The Mask_ into a film, after having seen other offers. The main character
went through several transformations, and the project was stalled a couple of
times.[3]

One unused "Mask" idea, according to Mike Richardson, was to transform the
story into one about a mask-maker who took faces off of corpses to put them on
teens and turn them into zombies.[4]

Initially intended to become a new horror franchise, New Line Cinema offered
the job of directing the film to Chuck Russell.[5] However, Russell found the
violence of the comic to be off-putting, and wanted the film be less grim and
more fun than the source material.[6]

Mike Werb says Chuck Russell tapped him after reading his script for _[Curious
George](/wiki/Curious_George_\(film\) "Curious George \(film\)")_ for
[Imagine](/wiki/Imagine_Entertainment "Imagine Entertainment"). The two
decided to turn _The Mask_ into a wild romantic comedy.[7] Mike Werb wrote his
first draft of _The Mask_ in less than six weeks, and less than two months
later it was green-lit.[8]

According to Mike Verheiden, they had a first draft screenplay for a film
version done back in 1990. Verheiden then wrote the second draft in early
1991, adding more humor, and that ended up being the only work he did on _The
Mask_. After that the film went into [development hell](/wiki/Development_hell
"Development hell").[9]

There were a lot of VFX scenes that had to be cut for budget.[10]

### Visual
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Visual effects")]

_The Mask_ 's visual effects were handled by [Industrial Light &
Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light & Magic") (ILM) and
[Digital Domain](/wiki/Digital_Domain "Digital Domain"). The sequences in the
film which involved [computer animation](/wiki/Computer_animation "Computer
animation") were supervised by ILM animation director [Wes
Takahashi](/wiki/Wes_Takahashi "Wes Takahashi").[11]

## Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Release")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Box office")]

The film was a box-office success, grossing $119 million domestically and over
$350 million worldwide,[2] becoming the second-highest grossing superhero
movie at that time, behind _[Batman](/wiki/Batman_\(1989_film\) "Batman \(1989
film\)")_. The film also received positive reviews from critics, including
[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") of the _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ , who gave the film 3 out
of 4 stars, noting Jim Carrey for his "joyful performance."[12] _The Mask_ is
one of three films featuring Carrey (the others being _[Ace Ventura: Pet
Detective](/wiki/Ace_Ventura:_Pet_Detective "Ace Ventura: Pet Detective")_ and
_[Dumb and Dumber](/wiki/Dumb_and_Dumber "Dumb and Dumber")_) released in 1994
that helped launch the actor to superstardom, though _The Mask_ was the most
successful of these three films both critically and commercially. The film is
also notable for immediately establishing Diaz – previously a complete unknown
– as a major star in Hollywood as well. The film is also considered a [cult
classic](/wiki/Cult_film "Cult film").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

It currently holds a 77% "Certified Fresh" rating on review aggregator website
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), with the consensus
stating "It misses perhaps as often as it hits, but Carrey's manic bombast,
Diaz's blowsy appeal, and the film's overall cartoony bombast keep _The Mask_
afloat."[13] On the television program _[Siskel& Ebert & the
Movies](/wiki/At_the_Movies_\(U.S._TV_series\) "At the Movies \(U.S. TV
series\)")_, the critics gave the film "two thumbs up".
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which assigns a normalized rating
out of 100 to reviews from film critics, gave _The Mask_ a rating score of 56,
indicating "mixed or average reviews" based on 12 reviews.

The film was nominated for [Best Visual
Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Visual_Effects "Academy Award for Visual
Effects") at the [67th Academy Awards](/wiki/67th_Academy_Awards "67th Academy
Awards"), but lost to _[Forrest Gump](/wiki/Forrest_Gump "Forrest Gump")._ In
addition, Carrey was nominated for a [Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe "Golden
Globe"). Conversely, he was also nominated for a [Razzie
Award](/wiki/Razzie_Award "Razzie Award") for "Worst New Star".

The film is also recognized by [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute") in these
lists:

  * 2005: [AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Movie_Quotes "AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes"): 
    * Stanley Ipkiss: "Somebody stop me!" – Nominated[14]
  * 2008: [AFI's 10 Top 10](/wiki/AFI%27s_10_Top_10 "AFI's 10 Top 10"): 
    * Nominated Fantasy Film[15]

## Home
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Home video")]

The film was released on VHS and [Laserdisc](/wiki/Laserdisc "Laserdisc") on
January 18, 1995, (and later on DVD) by [New Line Home
Video](/wiki/New_Line_Home_Entertainment "New Line Home Entertainment"). The
VHS version included an interview between Jim Carrey and [Space
Ghost](/wiki/Space_Ghost "Space Ghost"), as a promotion for their corporate
sibling Cartoon Network's [Space Ghost Coast to
Coast](/wiki/Space_Ghost_Coast_to_Coast "Space Ghost Coast to Coast") after
the film. It also had a trailer for Jim Carrey's then-upcoming film, _Dumb and
Dumber_ , and ads for the soundtrack to the film, and for what was then
branded as [Betty Crocker Pop Secret](/wiki/Pop_Secret "Pop Secret"). It was
later released on [Blu-ray Disc](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") on
December 9, 2008.[16] It has an [aspect ratio](/wiki/Image_aspect_ratio "Image
aspect ratio") of 1.85:1 and is encoded in [1080p](/wiki/1080p
"1080p")/[VC-1](/wiki/VC-1 "VC-1"). Its audio is a 5.1 [Dolby
TrueHD](/wiki/Dolby_TrueHD "Dolby TrueHD") encoded at a 16 bit / 48 kHz sample
rate. Special features include additional scenes, production details and two
[commentary tracks](/wiki/Commentary_track "Commentary track"), one by
director Chuck Russell and the other by the rest of the production crew.

##
Adaptations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Adaptations")]

An animated television series was made, _[The Mask: Animated
Series](/wiki/The_Mask:_Animated_Series "The Mask: Animated Series")_ , and a
video game for the Super Nintendo, _[The Mask](/wiki/The_Mask_\(video_game\)
"The Mask \(video game\)")_ , were both based on the film.

## Sequel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Sequel")]

After the success of the original, a sequel was planned, with magazine
[Nintendo Power](/wiki/Nintendo_Power "Nintendo Power") offering readers a
chance, via [sweepstakes](/wiki/Sweepstakes "Sweepstakes"), to win a cameo
role in the film.[17] However Jim Carrey eventually bailed on the project
forcing, amongst other things, for Nintendo Power to give the winner of the
contest the equivalent cash value instead.[17] A critically panned sequel,
_[Son of the Mask](/wiki/Son_of_the_Mask "Son of the Mask")_ , not featuring
Carrey, was eventually released in 2005.

## Possible third
film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Mask_\(film\)&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Possible third film")]

On the possibility of a third film, Mike Richardson has said, "We've been
talking about reviving _The Mask_ , both in film and in comics. We've had a
couple of false starts."[18]
